The hotel has a bar with a clubby atmosphere that feels Edwardian and is located close to many bars. The hotel lobby can be busy with guests.

The Carlyle has a lively bar (Bemelmans) with live jazz music and a supper club (Cafe Carlyle) that attracts an interesting mix of people, including celebrities. It also offers afternoon tea in the Gallery.

The Franklin Hotel offers a wine and cheese reception in the evening, which encourages guests to relax and get to know each other. The small size of the breakfast area and front parlor also facilitates interaction with other patrons.

The hotel is Irish-owned and has connections to many of the local bars in the Times Square area, including Bourbon Street bar downstairs which offers food, cocktails and a cool atmosphere. The adjacent pub is hopping each night, with a local-type crowd.

The hotel lobby was never busy, so it never felt crowded, and staff members were friendly and helpful, sometimes having real conversations with guests. The hotel sells local art, aiming to incorporate a true New York experience.

There is no bar/restaurant in this hotel, but there are vending machines in the basement along with a water/ice dispenser and a basement cafe center with breakfast. The hotel is located a few blocks from Times Square.
No information about opportunities to meet new people at this hotel can be extracted from the reviews.
The hotel guests seem to consist mostly of young bargain travelers. The hotel is described as being like a campground without the tents or a hostel without sufficient facilities.

The hotel has a breakfast room, two computers in the lobby for guests to use for emailing, a small gift shop, and an information desk for reservations of shows and tours. Some reviewers mention meeting nice or helpful staff.

I am sorry, there is no information about opportunities to meet new people at this hotel. The hotel is described as having permanent residents, and some reviewers noted the presence of an elevator operator.
There is a bar in the hotel. The hotel is a manageable size.

This is a budget-friendly hotel with a central location near attractions and subway stations, offering a lobby lounge with free coffee/tea, and attracting a diverse clientele, including tourists from different countries. The hotel includes amenities such as a guest laundry room and internet access in the lobby.

There is a lounge with free tea and coffee available for guests, but no restaurant or bar in the hotel. Reviewers note that the hotel is located in Chinatown, which may not be ideal for those unfamiliar with the area, and that there are limited options for nightlife nearby.
The hotel has a small bar on the second floor that serves reasonably priced drinks. The lobby has couches, flat screens, and two computers for guest use.
The Inn has a bar in the basement with an outdoor patio. It also has Lady Mendl's Tea Salon which hosts events such as wedding showers.

The hotel has a small bar, and the lobby and library are inviting. However, many reviews mention the hotel has small rooms and a relatively small lobby, with a library instead of a large communal space.

The shared bathrooms are a place to meet other hotel guests, including young adults from various countries and longer-term residents. The hotel also has a bar and lounge area that hosts parties with live bands.

The Kimberly has a restaurant and bar that are connected to the hotel, and the hotel is relatively small in size, which allows for more personal service. It is near a lot of bars, restaurants and pubs.
The Lombardy has a bar and a restaurant next door, and is near many restaurants, diners, and bars. Some reviews mention friendly staff.
The London NYC has a lively bar scene that attracts a certain standard of clientele. The lobby is small with no seating, which may lead to people standing around and socializing while waiting.
The hotel is located on a busy stretch of Amsterdam Avenue with restaurants and bars, and the lobby can be busy. Some reviewers mention meeting locals in the hotel restaurant, Nice Matin.

The hotel has a bar and common living room on the top floor where you can find free newspapers and coffee from 11am to 4 pm. There is a guest lounge on the 26th floor that had coffee, tea, ice tea and cookies all day from 11am and a bar opens at 4pm.

The Mansfield Hotel features a library with a fireplace, a bar/breakfast area, and a lobby lounge, where guests can relax and socialize; solo travelers found it easy to chat with fellow guests during breakfast. The hotel bar sometimes has live jazz music in the evenings.

The Marcel has a separate bar/restaurant next door that is a neighborhood hot spot and lively. There is a 10th-floor lounge and roof terrace where guests can socialize, and there was a complimentary wine and cheese reception in the lounge at 6 pm on weekdays.

The hotel has a lively atmosphere and a popular bar and terrace, making it a great meeting place, especially on weekends when it's crowded with a high-energy crowd. The lobby is also a social space and is visited by city locals who come to enjoy the bar, restaurants, and ballroom.
The Mark's bar area is small, and the hotel is frequented by non-resident actors. The hotel restaurant and bar are wonderful.
The Marmara Manhattan is an apartment-style hotel with no bar, restaurant, or concierge. Reviews mention that the surrounding area is residential.
There is no public space, and the lobby has no seating. The hotel is described as more of an upscale hostel and a trendy apartment building.

The hotel lobby is a comfortable place to sit, lounge around, have breakfast or a drink, and is open only to hotel residents and their guests. The lobby's atmosphere is described as warm, friendly, relaxed, cozy, hip, and great for people-watching, sometimes with celebrities present.

The hotel has a lobby bar and is described as small, making it easy to meet people, with a bartender known to engage guests in conversation. The lobby hosts a complimentary coffee service in the morning.

The hotel is near the Jewish Community Center pool and has a continental breakfast that can be crowded, which may provide opportunities to meet other guests. The hotel also has a library and a small gym.

The hotel hosts a wine reception every evening in the lobby, which some reviewers found to be a good opportunity to meet other couples from around the world. The bar is noted as being a chic hangout where locals line the bar before dinner, and the lobby is a welcoming environment for meeting friends.

There is a bar in the hotel and the lobby is mentioned as a place to greet guests, but some found the staff to be rude, the service poor, and the atmosphere stuck up. There are mentions of helpful staff, a friendly atmosphere, and good service but these were in the context of everything except the bar and the lobby.

The New Yorker Hotel has a bustling lobby with security, and the Tick Tock Diner is attached to the hotel, which can be a place to meet people. The hotel is a busy place with lots of people coming and going and near Madison Square Garden.

The hotel has a lobby lounge and bar that appear to be popular spots, and some reviewers mentioned friendly staff, including elevator operators. Some reviewers mentioned the hotel had elevator operators and a doorman.
The hotel has a lively bar that is good for people watching. The lobby also serves as a breakfast area.

The Pod Hotel has a funky lobby, a rooftop patio area where people socialize, and a French bar right next door that is a good place to meet people. The hotel seems to attract younger travelers, and is great for groups and singles who are out and about.

The hotel offers a complimentary evening reception with drinks and hors d'oeuvres, as well as a complimentary continental breakfast. Some reviewers noted that the staff was not as friendly as other hotels they had visited.
The hotel lobby bar has an atmosphere like a private club, with a good location for people-watching and a great bartender. The hotel is known to host celebrities, which can draw crowds outside.
The Roosevelt Hotel has a lobby bar, which some reviewers found lively and conducive to meeting people. A rooftop bar, Mad46, is also mentioned.

The Sherry-Netherland is a smaller, more intimate hotel with approximately 50 rooms and suites, primarily a residential building. Reviews mention that the staff is very personal and greets guests by name, but some found the front desk staff to be not very nice.
The Shoreham has a bar that is popular with locals and hotel guests. It also attracts a more eclectic crowd than the usual business hotel.

The King Cole Bar is a popular spot for people-watching and mingling, especially with midtown executives during lunchtime. The hotel also has lounges in small rooms off the lobby with intimate seating arrangements.
The hotel has a packed bar scene, and several lounge spaces on the ground floor that are popular. The hotel attracts a trendy crowd and hip internationals.

There are no mentions of public spaces or social activities that would facilitate meeting new people. Many reviews highlight the hotel's quiet location and spacious rooms, which may not be conducive to social interaction.

The Sylvan Guest House is located in Harlem, near a grocery store and multiple subway lines. Some reviewers mentioned hosting guests at the house and having nice contact with people in the neighborhood.
The hotel has a trendy bar/lounge that is busy with non-hotel guests, especially on weekends, and can be noisy on lower floors. Some reviewers found the bar staff unfriendly and lazy.
The lobby is a popular gathering place with bars and restaurants. The hotel hosts weddings, business meetings, and other events.

The Westin has a lobby bar and is connected to an entertainment complex that includes a movie theater and restaurants. Some reviewers mentioned that Shula's restaurant and Bar 10 are nice places to mingle with the staff.

The hotel has a downstairs bar, "Zana's," which is noted as a spot where one can meet fellow travelers and natives. Some reviewers also mention meeting people in the "Crooked Knife" bar located across the street.

The hotel has a bar on the 7th floor with a terrace, a chic bar, a lively neighborhood and doormen who were by all the ladies in the hotel would gladly stop & stare at them. The hotel made all the guests feel welcome & friendly and also a fantastic place to meet the odd celebrity.
This hotel is located near many local attractions and often hosts international travellers. There is a deli downstairs and a small gift shop in the lobby.

The hotel has a trendy, energetic bar and lounge area that is open until late, and is often busy with people from outside the hotel. This hotel has an open atrium lobby, which can be wonderful in the afternoon or evening.
The hotel has a small lobby and a bar in the Jean-Georges restaurant with limited seats. Some reviewers mentioned meeting celebrities at the hotel.

While some reviewers found the bar to be a bit stuffy and business-like, there is an Irish bar right across the street. The hotel is near McFadden's which has a fun atmosphere and is mentioned as a place to meet people.

There is a bar open from 5 PM to 11 PM that some guests enjoyed, with some reviewers mentioning friendly staff. The hotel also has a computer room with free internet access in the lobby for guest use.

The hotel has a bar called Wet, that is a bit of a scene, with loud music and a younger crowd. The hotel bar is also a great place to relax and unwind, but the atmosphere changes about 11pm when the locals come in and it gets very lively and is great fun.

The hotel shares facilities with the W Court next door, including a bar that is quite busy at night and a better "living room" lobby, but reviewers mention that the bar in the Tuscany isn't always open. Some reviewers comment on the staff being friendly and suggest sitting on the lobby couch long enough to land a date.
The W Times Square has a trendy lobby bar that is hopping and a popular spot for both guests and non-guests. Some reviewers mention a lively atmosphere, DJs, and good-looking clientele.

The hotel has a lively lobby bar that attracts a mix of hipsters, locals, and tourists, which can be crowded and noisy, especially in the evenings. There is also a basement nightclub called Underbar for drinks and music.
The hotel has a lounge on the 26th floor and a very busy main lobby. The hotel also has restaurants and bars.

The hotel is located in the Financial District, which is quiet on weekends, and reviewers noted a mix of European and business travelers. Behind the hotel is Stone Street, a pedestrian-friendly street with an assortment of restaurants, and Ulysses Bar is across the street.
The hotel has a lively bar with a great atmosphere and leather couches. The lobby is small, which can make it crowded.

The hotel bar and adjacent sports bar offer opportunities to socialize, and the staff, especially the door staff, are known for recommending places to go out. The hotel's central location near Times Square, theaters, and restaurants may also facilitate meeting other tourists.

The hotel bar and restaurant are frequented by locals, and buskers/chess players are often in nearby Washington Square. The hotel is located near NYU, which gives way to a younger crowd in the evenings.
The lobby is frequently bustling and busy with people, and is a popular hotel for tour groups. The hotel also has a bar/restaurant that can be entered from the lobby.
The hotel has an owner's lounge that serves continental breakfast and evening hors d'oeuvres, but it can get crowded. The staff is helpful with things such as hailing a taxi or making reservations.
The hotel has a small lobby and mezzanine area with a large TV, and a bar and restaurant on site. There's also free Internet access in the lounge area.

The Wolcott Hotel is a popular spot for European school groups and tourists, with common areas that encourage guest interaction such as coffee and muffins in the lobby every morning. The hotel also has a tour agent in the lobby and is centrally located near many attractions.

Many reviews mention that this is an apartment-style hotel, not a full-service hotel, with no daily maid service, and some reviews state that other residents live in the building. The front desk is not staffed 24/7.

The hotel has a bar and lobby area where people can meet, and computers in booths in the lobby for socializing, and the hotel staff are particularly friendly. Some reviews mention the hotel having a nice 10th-floor terrace and a restaurant.
